loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Luisa

texts.en: Luisa is a 39-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a fishing/fish vending business. She lives in Victorias, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2000 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her fishing/fish vending business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 4,500. Luisa is borrowing PHP 26,000 so that she can repair her fishing boat and purchase net and copper for fishing. This will be her 17th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 22,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Luisa aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way.

loans.use: to repair her fishing boat and purchase net and copper for fishing

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Angeles

texts.en:
Angeles G. is from the village of Abu, Baylao, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 44 years old, married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Angeles owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling canned goods, junk foods and detergents in the local community. Angeles has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2010, Angeles joined Kiva partner, HSPFI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI. This loan was used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. Angeles is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell such as beverages and junk foods. This loan will be her second from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell such as beverages and junk foods

loans.name: Loice

texts.en:
Loice is a mother of seven children aged between 11 and 25; some are in post-secondary education while others are in primary school. Loice is a farmer practising mixed farming in the western Kenyan town of Kitale. She produces milk and maize and sells them to the local market.
Loice has requested a loan of 30,000 KES from Kiva partner, Juhudi Kilimo, in order to venture into poultry farming. Her previous first loan of 40,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo was promptly paid back. She is focusing on running the poultry business effectively to be able to keep over 1,000 birds, pay back her loan and be the main egg supplier in her area. Loice says she is aware of the challenges of poultry disease but is optimistic she will succeed.

loans.use: to purchase poultry

loans.name: Math

texts.en:
Math S., 41, and her husband, 38, support their family by fishing with fishing implements along the Mekong River. They always take the fish they have caught to sell in the busy market. If they have some fish left over, they will turn them into dried fish or fish paste.This couple can earn a profit from this business of $10 each day to help support their family.  

Math S. says that she and her husband can transport their fish by using their existing motorbike, but now it has broken down. The couple wishes to buy a new one but they don’t have enough money to do that. In order to deal with this problem, Math S. is applying for a loan to buy a used  motorbike to replace the broken one.

loans.use: to buy a used to motorbike to replace the broken one

loans.name: Shiela May

texts.en:
Shiela May is a 37-year-old married woman with four children. Her oldest child is 11 years old. Her husband works as a farmer and driver.
Shiela May is a farmer and raises pigs. She helps her husband in planting rice crops and weeding. She also makes sure the pigs she grows are healthy. She does her best to help sustain her family. This loan will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and pig feed.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and pig feed

loans.name: Margret

texts.en: Margret is a 40-year-old single mother of six children living in her own house in Fort Portal, Uganda. She is charged with the responsibility of looking after the family and her desire is to complete construction of her house and to educate her children. Margret sells fresh foods for a living and has been in this kind of business for 20 years. With her business income, she has been able to buy land, cattle and build a house. She faces the challenge of irregular sales. Her dream is to set up a food store. Margret is requesting a loan to buy fresh foods for resale.

loans.use: to buy fresh foods for resale

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David is 51 years old and married with seven children aged between 10 and 26. Five of the children are currently attending school. David is a dairy farmer from Litein town in Rift Valley, Kenya. He has been farming for 26 years. His farm produces milk, which is sold to the local market. He also earns income from his small-scale farming of tea, which is also sold locally. He mainly depends on the income from his farm to cater for the basic needs of his family.
David has a good record with Kiva partner, Juhudi Kilimo, after he successfully repaid his previous loan of 100,000 KES. He has requested this loan of 70,000 KES to purchase a dairy cow. He believes that, with the dairy cow he will acquire, his milk production will increase and this will earn him more income. He will use this income to improve his family's standard of living.

loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Bernardita

texts.en:
Bernardita M. is from the village of Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 37 years old, single and has one infant-aged children. To make a living, Bernardita owns and operates a specialized retail store selling health and medicinal products such as merthiolate and bethadine in the local community. She also sells detergents and dishwashing solutions. Bernardita has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 7,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2011, Bernardita joined Kiva partner, HSPFI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell such as detergents and multivitamins. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell such as detergents and multivitamins

loans.name: Mary Grace Pastor's Group

texts.en:
Mary Grace P. is from the village of Simmimbaan. She is the leader of an eight-member group loan offered by Kiva partner, ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Mary Grace P. Group.
Mary Grace is 34 years old, married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a bakery, baking and selling a variety of baked goods in the local community. Mary Grace has been engaged in her business for over 17 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2011, Mary Grace joined Kiva partner, ASKI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase baking equipment. This loan will be her first from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase baking equipment

loans.name: Munnawar's Group

texts.en:
Munnawar lives in Khanewal, a small city in the Punjab Province of Pakistan known for its agriculture.  She has been living there in the area of Jaswant Nagar in a two-room brick house with her family for past 20 years.  She is married to M. M. who works at a private company for a reasonable income every month, and has two daughters who are both enrolled in a local school.

Munnawar is a very supportive lady by nature. She carries out her responsibilities as a housewife, and besides her household work, she also supports her family financially by selling clothes to customers in her neighborhood. She visits Multan, a historic city famous for its embroidery art, once a month to buy clothes for resale.

Munnawar has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to buy clothes in bulk to offer more variety to her clients and, hopefully, to earn more profits.  Buying in bulk will reduce the time and cost of travel to Multan, as she won't need to make as many buying trips.  She has had her business for five years and is hopeful that further investment will put her business in a more profitable position.

Note: In the photo that accompanies this profile, Munnawar is the woman whose hand is raised.

loans.use: to buy clothes in bulk for resale

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita M. is from the village of Tagdo, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 42 years old, married, and has four grown children. To make a living, Nenita has a sari-sari (variety) retail shop where she sells daily use products such as shampoo and soap, and foodstuffs such as canned goods, snacks, and candy. Nenita has had her business for more than a year and earns about 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month.

In 2011, Nenita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services with the hope of  improving her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nenita is requesting her first loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase inventory for her shop.  She plans to reinvest any additional revenue generated as a result of the loan back into her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaches out to poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase food and other inventory for a small variety store

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en:
Merlinda T. is from the village of Goin, Liloy, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 46 years old, married, and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Merlinda runs a small shop where she sells daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste. Merlinda has just started this business.

In 2011, Merlinda joined Kiva field partner PMPC to gain access to financial services with the hope of  improving her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Merlinda is requesting her first loan of 3,000 Philippine pesos, which will be used to purchase inventory for her shop. She plans to use any additional revenue generated from the business as a result of the loan to supplement her family's income. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase shampoo, soap, and other products to sell at a small variety store

loans.name: Vyacheslav

texts.en:
Vyacheslav is married and has two sons. He is a businessman from Novomoskovsk. He owns two fast food kiosks selling meat pastries, instant coffee, hot tea and baked goods. He has two vending locations at different markets in his hometown. A hired vendor works at one of his fast food kiosks. Vyaheslav has been in this business for eleven years. His monthly net profit amounts to about $640. 

Vyacheslav is seeking a loan of 8,000 UAH to purchase additional equipment to start making vareniki – a national Ukraininan food, also called perogies. This will allow him to increase sales in the summertime. Food items are always in high demand, despite dead season tendencies. This is why Vyacheslav believes this type of business will keep bringing in good profits for him and his family.

loans.use: to purchase additional equipment

loans.name: Chyrell

texts.en: Chyrell is a married woman who lives in the island of Cebu. She earns her living by operating a general store. Her husband Ronald, who is 32 years old, works as a driver to earn his living. They have four children who are between 1 and 15 years old. Chyrell joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Chyrell has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 9,800, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her fifth loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000 to buy groceries to sell in her general store so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Chyrell is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: to purchase groceries for her store

loans.name: Elisa

texts.en:
Elisa D. is from the village of Palomoc, Titay, Zamboanga Sibugay. She is 42 years old. Elisa is married and has seven school-aged children. To make a living, Elisa owns and operates a business venture in the services sector operating a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing general services to local community members. Elisa has been engaged in her business for over twenty years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Elisa joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elisa is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase equipment to improve the business. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Elisa from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase equipment to improve the business

loans.name: Jimmy

texts.en:
Jimmy O. is from the village of Butay, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. He is 51 years old. Jimmy is married and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, he owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling detergents, canned goods and spices in the local community. He has been engaged in his business for over eleven years and earns approximately $125 a month for these activities.

In 2011, Jimmy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jimmy is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell, like canned goods and snack foods. This will be his 1st loan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet R. is from the village of Imbatuhon, Liong, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 38 years old. Juliet is married and has seven school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a specialized retail store, buying and selling coconuts for copras (coconut meat for making oil) in the local community. Juliet has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately $75 a month for these activities.

In 2011, Juliet joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Juliet is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional coconuts to sell. This will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Indelicia

texts.en: Indelicia is a married woman who lives in Bogo, Cebu. She earns her living by operating a business making ice cream. Her husband Mauro, who is 36 years old, works as an ice cream vendor to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities.  They have four children who are between 5 and 12 years old. Indelicia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Indelicia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 4,300, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her fifth loan, she is borrowing PHP 13,000 to buy salt, milk, and peanuts so that she can continue to save up for the future renovation of her house and the education of her children. Indelicia is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients for making ice cream

loans.name: Mechelle

texts.en:
Mechelle V. is from the village of Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 30 years old. Mechelle is separated from her spouse and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Mechelle owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling ready to wear clothing and blankets, and she also sells beauty products from NATASHA and AVON in the local community. She sells silver-plated jewelry as well. Mechelle has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately $125 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Mechelle joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. 

Mechelle is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like t-shirts, blouses and pillow cases. This will be her 3rd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell like t-shirts, blouses and pillow cases

loans.name: Hem

texts.en:
Mrs. Hem P., age 40, has been a primary school teacher since 1990 and earns an income about $1.60 per day. Her husband, Much Samen, age 43, is a construction worker, and he can make a profit of approximately $1.60 per day. They have two children, but their children don’t have jobs yet. 

Mrs. Hem P. will be using her loan to add to her personal savings to buy a plot of farmland near her house, which is a good location for farming. She will rent out this land to farmers for a fee. She says that this loan will provide her with an additional new fixed asset. 

Mrs. Hem P. and her husband were taken in the photo.

loans.use: to buy a plot of farmland to rent to a farmer

loans.name: Antonia

texts.en:
Antonia A. is from the village of Kabuhi, Pandan, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 47 years old. Antonia is married and has three adult children. 

To make a living, Antonia makes and sells coconut oil and coco charcoal in the local community. Antonia has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Antonia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Antonia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. 

Antonia is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase coconuts for making products to sell. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Antonia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase coconuts for making products to sell

loans.name: William

texts.en:
William L., 44, is a married father of eight children whose ages range between 1 and 18 years. Six of the children are currently attending school. 

He is a farmer from the town of Litein in the Rift Valley of Kenya, where he has been practicing mixed farming for ten years. He employs one farmhand and sells his milk to the local market. He also operates a retail shop in the same town.

He has requested a loan of 60,000 KES through Kiva partner Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will be invested towards the education of his children. 

He would like to have at least four pure breed dairy cows and a water pump in the future. His major challenges have been diseases and lack of enough animal feed and water.

loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en:
Lilian S. is aged 49 and married with six children between 28 and 11 years old, with three still in school. 

She has been engaged in mixed farming for over 10 years in her hometown of Kitale in Western Kenya. She solely relies on farming for her family's needs. She sells her produce of vegetables, maize and beans locally.

Lilian has requested this loan amounting to 31,200 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow with this being her first loan request. She says the dairy cow will improve the family income through milk produce and make the education of the children a possibility.

Lilian's challenges are animal diseases and food shortage. She is full of compliments to Juhudi Kilimo for the loan services.

loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Luciana

texts.en:
Luciana A. is from the village of Upper Cogon, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 53 years old. Luciana is widowed and has one adult child. 

To make a living, Luciana owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling instant noodles, baby diapers, napkins and sanitary tissues in the local community. Luciana has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Luciana joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Luciana has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. 

Luciana is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods and noodles. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Luciana from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business.

loans.name: Phat

texts.en:
Phat H. resides with her family in Prey Veng province, Cambodia, an area known as the largest rice-producing region in Cambodia. H. is a housewife, while her husband sells firewood, earning an income of US $2.5 per day. Each month, the family has to spend US $41 on food and US $90 on other necessary expenses. 

H. is requesting a loan of US $1,000 to purchase a truck to transport firewood to sell. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy a truck to transport firewood to sell

loans.name: Ailyn

texts.en:
Ailyn M. is from the village of Maac, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 30 years old. Ailyn is married and has five school-aged children. 

To make a living, Ailyn buys and sells seafood products including fish like milk fish and sardines. Ailyn has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Ailyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Ailyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. 

Ailyn is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell like milk fish and mackerel. This will be the second loan taken out by Ailyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Oeur

texts.en: Oeur K., 27, has been a tailor at Bekchan market, Phnom Penh City, Cambodia, since 2007, earning an average profit $3.25 per day. Her husband  is a construction worker who earns about $4.5 per day. Oeur is requesting a loan of $1,100 to buy a new motorcycle for easier and cheaper access to her business location and for general transportation. In the future, she plans to open a tailor shop, buy a new house and enable her child to achieve a high education level, her first priority.

loans.use: to buy a new motorcycle for transportation

loans.name: Tina

texts.en:
Tina is divorced. She has two grown children: a son, Leonid, and a daughter, Victoria. 

She is an entrepreneur from Novomoskovsk. Tina sells menswear in the central marketplace of her home town. Her son is actively helping her run the clothing venture. She always tries to keep up with fashion trends and re-stocks her inventory on a regular basis. Tina has been in the trade for ten years. Her monthly net profit amounts to about 7,000 UAH. 

Tina can be characterized as a loyal and consistent partner and a reliable borrower. This time, Tina is requesting a loan of 20,000 UAH to purchase spring jackets. Tina is hoping to continue expanding her business and providing for her family. Tina’s business goal is to start a second location by the fall of this year.

loans.use: to purchase spring jackets

loans.name: Duch

texts.en:
Duch Y., 40, resides in Prey Veng province, Cambodia, an area known as one of the largest rice-producing regions in Cambodia. 

Y. is a housewife, while her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of US $3 per day. Each month, the family has to spend US $33 on food and US $50 on the other necessary expenses. 

Y. is requesting a loan of US $1,000 to purchase groceries to sell. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy groceries to resell

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine P. is 57 years old, married, and has one adult child. She is currently residing in Libertad, Sapang Dalaga.  She earns a living by making snacks and other delicacies to sell in the local community. She has been in this business for many years. 

In 2005, Josephine joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josephine has successfully repaid a previous loan of 22,000 PHP from PMPC, which was used to invest in expanding her business. Josephine is requesting a new loan of 35,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products to sell. This loan will be Josephine's 19th loan PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients to make snacks

loans.name: Venancia

texts.en:
Venancia L. is from the village of Kayok, Liloy, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 58 years old, married, and has two adult children. To make a living, Venancia owns and operates a clothing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing general clothing services to local community members. Venancia has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month.

In 2011, Venancia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Venancia is requesting a loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be Venancia's first loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.name: Dy

texts.en: Dy O. is 40 years old and resides in Prey Veng province, Cambodia, an area known as one of the largest rice producing regions in Cambodia. O. is employed at the garment factory, earning an income of $3 per day. Each month, the family has to spend $20 on food and $50 on other necessary expenses. O. is requesting a loan of $1,000 to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Mwanabarawa

texts.en:
Mwanabarawa is a married woman with 5 school-going children. They own a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. For the past three years, she has operated a retail business selling household goods to her neighbors and passersby. She operates from Monday to Friday, selling consumable goods on a daily basis. 

Mwanabarawa faces a major challenge of theft because of insecurity in her place of operation. She dreams of establishing a wholesale shop in the future. With the 30,000 KES loan she is requesting, she wants to purchase 10 bundles of maize flour, one sack of beans and cooking oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase 10 bundles of maize flour, one sack of beans and cooking oil

loans.name: Chourn

texts.en: Chourn R. resides with her family in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean temples. R. is employed at the garment factory, earning an income of 3 USD per day. Each month, the family has to spend 41 USD on food and 90 USD on other necessary expenses. R. is requesting a loan of 1,000 USD to purchase blacksmith equipment for her brother to start a business. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her second loan from CREDIT, a long standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy blacksmith equipment to start a new business

loans.name: Brenda

texts.en:
Brenda R. is from the village of Manila Group, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 42 years old. Brenda is married and has 7 school-aged children. To make a living, Brenda owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from making and selling snacks and other delicacies like fishballs, kekiam, siomai and tempura in the local community. Brenda has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities. In the picture is Brenda and two of her children.

In 2010, Brenda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Brenda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Brenda is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed like cooking oil, raw kekiam and tempura. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Brenda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

texts.en: Hourn S. resides with her family in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean temples. S. is a farmer, earning an income of $2 per day. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of about $3 per day. Each month, the family has to spend $18 on food and $40 on other necessary expenses. S. is requesting a loan of $800 to purchase car spare parts to sell. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be Say's first loan from CREDIT, a long standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: To purchase car spare parts to sell

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en: Mary Jane is a married woman who lives in Narra, Palawan. She earns her living by operating three business ventures:  hog raising, rice retailing and vegetable vending. Her husband Allan, who is 40 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living and helps in his wife's business activities.  They have four children who are between 7 and 13 years old. Mary Jane joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 15 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Mary Jane has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 24,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 7,800, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 16th loan, she is borrowing PHP 25,000 to buy livestock supplies and rice so that she can continue to save up for the future expansion of her business. Mary Jane is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: to buy supplies for her pigs and rice

loans.name: Norielyn

texts.en:
Norielyn M. is 34 years old, married and has three school-aged children. She is from the village of Manila Group within Wao municipality, a part of Lanao del Sur province on the islands of Mindanao. Norielyn runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop from which she sells daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snacks and beverages to the local community. Norielyn has been in business for over five years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Norielyn joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI which was used to purchase additional inventory and obtain some working capital. Norielyn is requesting a new loan, her second from HSPFI, of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional canned goods and snacks to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business.

texts.ar: بلال في عمر 36 سنة متزوج وله 3 اولاد يعمل في بيع وتصليح الاشكمانات للسيارات له في عمله 14 سنة يحب عمله له تاريخ جيد مع المجموعة وكان يلقى الدعم الكامل يريد من خلال طلب قرض من المجموعة الى شراء بضاعة للعمل وهو نشيط في عمله ومميز يواجه منافسة في محيطه ولكنه يتميز بالتعامل الجيد والدقة في العمل يحب اولاده ويريد ان يؤمن لهم العيش الجيد والكريم
texts.en: Bilal is a 36-year-old husband and father of three who very much loves his children and seeks to secure a dignified life for them. Bilal enjoys 14 years of experience selling and repairing automotive exhaust systems. He distinguishes himself among his competition through his considerable energy, thoroughness, and excellent customer service. Given his good standing with Al Majmoua, Bilal now wanted to seek another loan to purchase automotive parts for his business.

loans.use: to purchase automotive parts for his business.

loans.name: Ing

texts.en:
Ing S. resides with her family in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorian temples. S. sells fruit, earning an income of 10 USD per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of about 5 USD per day. Each month, the family has to spend 40 USD on food and 50 USD on other necessary expenses.

S. is requesting a loan of 1,200 USD. This will be her second loan from CREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner. She would like to purchase more fruit to resell. In the future, she would like to use any additional income to repair her house.

loans.use: To buy more fruit to resell

loans.name: Miriam

texts.en: Miriam is a married woman who supports her family by operating a business buying and selling scrap. She lives in the island of Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2009 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her scrap business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 3,360. Miriam is borrowing PHP 10,000 to buy scrap metal and plastic to resell. This will be her fifth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 6,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Miriam aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.

loans.use: To buy scrap metal and plastic

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Ester is 53 years old and married with eight children. With four children in school, Ester works very hard to provide for them.

Ester runs a general store in the Philippines. She is requesting a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional goods to sell.

Ester has been in this business for five years and sells a variety of items such as canned goods, sweet items and other miscellaneous items.  

In the future, Ester would like to expand her business and to finish the education of her children.

Accordingly, he would like to petition Al Majmoua for a loan to purchase supplies of fabric and foam for his work.

loans.name: Batsuren

texts.en:
Batsuren is 36 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They live together in a studio apartment which they bought under leasing contract. Her two sons, 2 and 16 years old, are attending local schools. 

Batsuren has operated a spare parts retail business since 2004 by renting a stall at “Auto Plaza”, the biggest spare parts market in city. Her husband, Erkhembayar, works with her as a salesperson. She buys brand new spare parts from Beijing, the capital city of China, and sells them on a profit. She also sells secondhand spare parts, which she collects, fixes and replenishes. She has her own customers and her products are in good demand. 

She is a very hardworking and energetic person. At this time she is working hard to be able to send her children all the way through college. She is requesting a loan to purchase more spare parts from Beijing.

loans.use: to buy more spare parts from China

loans.name: Susan

texts.en: Susan is a married woman who lives in Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a food vending business. Her husband Alfredo, who is 57 years old, works as a helper to earn his living. They have eight children who are between 13 and 39 years old. Susan joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Susan has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 9,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 4,500, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her fifth loan, she is borrowing PHP 11,000 to purchase stock for her food vending business so that she can continue to save up for future family needs. Susan is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: to purchase more food to sell

loans.name: Mary Grace

Mary Grace joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2009 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past three loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Mary Grace has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 12,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her fourth loan, she is borrowing PHP 20,000 to buy stock so that she can continue to save up for the future expansion of her business. Mary Grace is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory for her general store

loans.name: Mwanamgeni

texts.en:
Mwanamgeni is a married woman with 3 children, 2 of whom still attend school. They own a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past two years, she has been selling fish at the market to her neighbors and passersby. Mwanamgeni faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. During the dry hot season, the available fish supply is inadequate. While during the cold winter season, the available fish is enough for supply. Mwanamgeni dreams of expanding and selling as a wholesaler in the future.

With the 30,000 KES she wants to purchase 5 sacks of fish for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access funds to boost her business.

With the help of her past 11 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Lourdes has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. loans.name: Nyirandi

texts.fr: Nyirandi M. J.  est entrepreneur, âgée de 35 ans, mariée, mère de 3 enfants.  Son conjoint est un boucher et  vendeur de la viande de vaches. La  cliente  Nyirandi M. J. s’entraide avec son mari dans cette activité spécialement dans la viande des porcs. Elle étale ses marchandises au marché sectoriel de Nyabushongo . Il ya 18 ans qu’elle exerce cette activité. Elle est au 14 cycle avec le crédit de l’IMF Hekima pour  renforcer  son capital. Ce nouveau crédit doit lui servir de s’approvisionner  avec  de nouvelles marchandises ( 3 porcs pour les revendre en viande).  En plus, elle ambitionne pérenniser  son entreprise et construire sa maison d’habitation. La cliente Nyirandi M. J. remercie l’IMF Hekima pour  ses actions dédiées aux pauvres femmes exclues de banque classique.
texts.en: Nyirandi M. J. is a 35 year-old entrepreneur.  She is married and the mother of 3 children.  Her husband is a butcher and sells beef.  Mrs. M. J. and her husband help each other in this business, especially with pork.  She displays her merchandise at the Nyabushongo sectoral market.  She has been in this business for 18 years.  This is her 14th loan cycle with the Hekima microfinance institution to expand her working capital.  This new loan should help her to stock up with new merchandise (3 pigs to be sold as pork meat).  In addition, her goals are to perpetuate her business and to build a house to live in.  Mrs. M. J. thanks the Hekima microfinance institution for its actions dedicated to poor women excluded from traditional banks.

loans.use: To buy 3 pigs to be sold as pork meat

loans.name: Alex

texts.en:
Alex is a 33-year-old married man with 4 children. His oldest child is only 9 years old.

Alex is a farmer. He tills his own land in the town of Banga, South Cotabato. Alex has been growing rice for more than 5 years and earns 20,000 PHP every harvest.

Alex's loan will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies. He wishes for his children to be successful someday.

To make a living, Maria owns and operates a fishing business. The main source of income for the business comes from harvesting and selling wild-caught fish in the local community. Maria has been engaged in her business for over 22 years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Maria joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maria is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Maria from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.name: Meas

texts.en: Meas K., a 46-year-old widow who sells a variety of cakes and sweets for a living, earns a daily profit of around $2 USD. Meas lives with her three single children, two all of whom are foremen in local construction earning a daily revenue of approximately $4.80, while her third child is a garment worker. Meas  is requesting a loan of $600 to assist her sons in purchasing more construction equipment. The net benefit of this loan will be additional family income.

loans.use: to purchase additional construction equipment for her sons

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David F. is from the village of Carugmanan, Banisilan, Cotabato. He is 63 years old. David is married and has 7 adult-aged children. To make a living, David owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as powder detergents, clorox, and powder juices in the local community. David has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, David joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. David has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and increase working capital. David is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods and snack foods. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by David from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business.

loans.name: Warlita

texts.en:
Warlita C. is 67 years old, married and has seven adult-aged children. She is from the village of Danao within Plaridel municipality, a part of Misamis Occidental province on the Mindanao islands. Warlita runs a general store from which she sells a variety of different products to the local community. She has been in business for over eleven years and earns approximately 18,000 PHP a month.

In 1999, Warlita joined PMPC to gain access to its financial services. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC which was used to purchase new items to expand her product offerings. Warlita is requesting a new loan, her nineteenth loan from PMPC, of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase retail products for her general store. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business.

loans.name: Edith

texts.en:
Edith S. is 59 years old, widowed and has seven adult-aged children. She is from the village of Kabatangan within the municipality of Wao, Lanao del Sur province on the Mindanao islands. Edith runs a sari-sari (variety) shop from which she buys and sells canned goods, snacks, bread, charcoal, biscuits and candies, plus vegetables like tomatoes, potatoes, bananas and also ice candy to the local community. Edith has been in business for over four years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Edith joined HSPFI to gain access to its financial services. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI which was used to purchase additional inventory and obtain some working capital. Edith is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, her second from HSPFI, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like beverages and canned goods. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business.

loans.name: Anecito

texts.en:
62-year-old Anecito R. lives with his family in the town of Banga in South Cotabato province on the Mindanao islands. He has seven children. 

Anecito is engaged in farming. He works hard to provide for his family, growing rice and corn crops and selling his harvest to the community. 

This loan will be used to purchase seeds and fertilizers. Anecito wishes for his family to have good health always.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Yasini

texts.en:
Yasini is a married man with six children, three of whom attend lower level school while one attends college. They own a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food for the family. For the past twenty years, he has operated a fish and crab selling business. He sells at the market to his neighbors and to tourists visiting the area. 

With the 40,000 Kenyan shillings he wants to purchase sacks of fish and crabs for sale. He faces a major challenge of seasonality in his business. Yasini dreams of expanding and establishing a wholesale shop in the future. He decided to join Yehu microfinance to access funds to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of fish and crabs for sale

loans.name: Moth

texts.en:
Moth E. is a 50-year-old fish vendor in and around her community, in Phnom Penh. She leaves home in the early morning to where fish are sold in bulk and buys fish from her suppliers. She then takes the fish back to sell for a profit. Moth E. has been operating this business for over five years and earns 4 USD a day. Her husband earns his daily money by driving a motor taxi. 

Moth E. is married with 8 children, 7 of whom are married and have already started new homes, and the other one is single. Two of her sons are blacksmiths. The main income depends mostly on her sons. In order make extra income, Moth E. will use her loan to help her son to buy iron to trim for resale, and to enlarge her fish-selling enterprise.

loans.use: to buy iron to trim for resale, and to enlarge her fish-selling enterprise

loans.name: Redempter

texts.en:
Redempter is 41 years old, a widow and has five children who are between the ages of 16 and 24 years old. All of her children are in school. She is a very hardworking woman. 

Redempter has sold clothes for the past sixteen years. She is also a tailor. She is requesting a loan to buy fabric to make school uniforms.

loans.use: To buy fabric to make school uniforms

loans.name: Nhek

texts.en:
Nhek N. resides with her family in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorian temples. Nhek is a farmer, earning an income of 1 USD per day. Her husband is a security guard, earning an income of about 5 USD per day. Each month the family has to spend 20 USD on food and 35 USD on other necessary expenses. 

Nhek is requesting a loan of 1,200 USD. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner. She would like to purchase a tuk tuk, a motorcycle-based taxi, for one of her family members to start a business. In the future, she would like to use any additional income to repair her house.

loans.use: To buy a tuk tuk

loans.name: Claudine

texts.en: Claudine, a 26-year-old mother of a 3 1/2-year-old child not yet in school, has been selling second-hand clothes for the past 7 years. This business has enabled her to meet the needs for her family. Claudine is requesting a loan to buy more used clothes in order to make more profits. She hopes to buy a piece of land from her profits and her savings.

loans.use: to buy more used clothes for sale.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary A. O. is forty-nine years old, married to a businessman, and they have two children aged twenty-three years old and eighteen years old. Her business is located near the Buxton-Kilifi stage in Mombasa, Kenya. Mombasa is the coastal region of Kenya and is well-known for its many tourist attractions, not forgetting the Indian Ocean's white beaches. 

Mary A. O. owns a restaurant in which she has been selling food and drinks to the local people for the last year. She has provided employment to one person. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has are financial constraints. However, she works very hard from early morning to late evening to keep her business doing well. 

She is using her loan of Kes 50,000 to buy fish and other food items to expand her business. She hopes to be a wholesaler in future. She describes herself as a customer-friendly lady.

loans.use: to buy fish and other food items.

loans.name: Hourt

texts.en:
Hourt P. resides with her family in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. P. is a farmer, earning an income of USD 1 per day. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of about USD 2 per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 40 on food and USD 80 on other necessary expenses. 

P. is requesting a loan of USD 700 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to use to commute to work. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.name: Diogene

texts.en:
Diogene is 30 years old. He has two children who are two months and five years old.The elder child goes to school while the young one hasn't begun school yet.

Diogene sells second-hand bags and it's a year now since he began selling these bags. He is requesting a loan to buy more bags for sale and with the profits he plans build a house.

loans.use: to purchase used bags for resale.

loans.name: Miraji

texts.en:
Miraji is married and has four children, two of whom attend school. He owns a house that has no electricity nor piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past five years, Miraji has operated a fish selling business, selling at the market and from home to his neighbors and friends. He plans to use this KES 20,000 loan to purchase three sacks of fish for sale. Miraji faces a major challenge of seasonality in his business. During the hot dry season, the availability of fish for sale is minimal while during the rainy winter season, the availability of fish is high in supply and demand is lower. Miraji dreams of supplying a large number of people in the future. He decided to work with Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: to purchase three sacks of fish for sale.

loans.name: Khatoon's Group

texts.en:
In order to meet her family's basic needs, Khatoon, a widow, started a boutique business after the death of her husband. She displays her stitched clothes in her boutique, selling them to different community members and clothing shops for good profits.

Khatoon has a son and 2 daughters. Her son, a motor mechanic by profession, is 25 years old. He couldn’t get an education due to financial constraints. Khatoon’s elder daughter, 17 years old, also left school after 5th year and she helps her mother in her business. Khatoon’s youngest daughter is 16 years old. The family lives in a 2-room brick house in the area of Jaswant Nagar in Khanewal, a small city in the Punjab region of Pakistan, known for its agriculture industry.

Khatoon is a very hardworking woman, managing her household duties very well, along with her business. She has applied for a loan from Kiva's partner, Asasah, to improve her boutique business. She will use the loan to buy clothes, beads and lace in bulk to prepare better and larger quantities of simple and designer dresses to sell and to earn better profits. Khatoon has good experience in her business and hopes that an investment will bring better profits to her and an expansion of her business.

Khatoon is a regular lender with Asasah and this is her 2nd loan application. In previous loan years, she has proved herself to be a responsible client by repaying her installments on time and attending every meeting.

loans.use: to buy clothes, beads and lace for her boutique

loans.name: Nelia

texts.en:
Nelia P. is from the village of Malaigang, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 42 years old, married and has 3 school-aged children. Nelia owns and operates a beauty salon providing hairdressing and beauty services to local community members. Nelia has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2011, Nelia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nelia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials such as hair dyes and hair solutions. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Nelia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase materials such as hair dyes and hair solutions

loans.name: Pha

texts.en: Pha C. lives with her family in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. C. is a weaver, earning an income of USD 2 per day. Her husband sells snacks, earning an income of about USD 3 per day. Each month, the family spends USD 50 on food and USD 60 on other necessary expenses. C. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase more raw silk to produce silk products. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her second loan from CREDIT, a long standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy more raw silk

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to renovate the salon

loans.name: Salome

texts.en:
Salome P. is from the village of Malaigang, Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 42 years old. Salome is married and has four adult children. To make a living, Salome owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling detergents, canned goods, diapers, sugar, eggs, shampoo & toothpaste in the local community. Salome has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Salome joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Salome is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like canned goods & beverages. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Salome from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell such as canned goods & beverages.

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna L. is from the village of Central Poblacion, Kalilangan, Bukidnon. She is 39 years old. Edna is married and has two very young children. To make a living, Edna owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling canned goods, detergents, shampoo, soap & snack foods in the local community. Edna has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities. In the picture are Edna and her daughter.

In 2011, Edna joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Edna is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, snack foods & detergents. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Edna from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods, snack foods & detergents.

loans.name: Sath

texts.en:
Sath S., 62, earns money to support her family by selling dried fish in Phnom Penh, in the middle of Cambodia. S. buys fish in bulk at a low price from her suppliers. She slices the fish into small pieces, mixes them with delicious ingredients, and dries them in the sunshine. A day later, she collects those fish to sell.

Sath was married, but her husband died of senility years ago. She has two children who are married, working, and living with her at home. Sath S. will use her loan to buy a cow to butcher and take its meat for resale. This will provide her with additional profit, which she will use to better meet her family’s needs.

loans.use: to buy a cow to butcher and sell the meat

loans.name: Melanie

texts.en:
Melanie L. is from the village of Macaopao, Kalilangan, Bukidnon. She is 30 years old. Melanie is married and has 2 very young children. To make a living, Melanie owns & operates a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing "motorela" or "habal-habal" (motorcycle transport) services  to local community members with her husband as the driver. Melanie has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Melanie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Melanie is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase tools needed for the maintenance of the service. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Melanie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase tools needed for the maintenance of the service.

loans.name: Burmakan

texts.en:
Burmakan M. is 56 and widowed. She lives with her son’s family in Kara – Balta town. She is engaged in selling vegetables at the local market. She started in 2001 and her husband helped a lot to develop this activity. Unfortunately , after his death in 2010, this business became unprofitable.

 In order to find an additional means of subsistence, Burmakan decided to start breed cattle. With the initial capital of 25,000 KGS she managed to earn 6,000 KGS a month from selling milk products. In order to develop her farm,  Burmakan has applied for a loan of 50,000 KGS, which will help her further broaden her business activities. In future, she plans to buy a flat in Kara-Balta town for her family. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Micro-finance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of micro-finance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase cattle.

loans.name: Delphine

texts.en: Delphine is 32 years old. She has four children who are between the ages of 3 and 13. She sells different types of used clothes. She has been selling used clothes for 3 years. She is requesting a loan to buy more used clothes for sale.

loans.use: to purchase more used clothes for resale.

loans.name: Emelita's Group

texts.en:
Emelita B. is from the village of San Luis, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 43 years old. Emelita is the group leader of a 8-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Emelita is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Emelita owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes  from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Emelita has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Emelita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emelita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Emelita is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Emelita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en:
Merlinda L. is from Carmen Annex, Ozamiz City. She is 47 years old and still single. She is currently engaged in a dressmaking business and at the same time she is working as a caregiver for two children. She has been engaged in this business for two years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In 2006, Merlinda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of   PHP 20,000 PHP from PMPC.

Merlinda is now requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be use to purchase additional materials in her dressmaking business. This will be her 5th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the living standard of her family.

About PMPC: 

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional materials for her dressmaking business.

loans.name: Wendy

texts.en:
Wendy T. is from the village of Macaopao, Kalilangan, Bukidnon. She is 33 years old. Wendy is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Wendy owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling ready-to-wear clothing such as T-shirts & blouses in the local community. She is also selling medicinal products like ointments. Wendy has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Wendy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Wendy is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional blouses & T-shirts to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Wendy from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional blouses & T-shirts to sell.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is married with two children aged six and two years, with the firstborn already in school. He has been doing mixed farming in his hometown of Nkubu in Central Kenya for six years now. His produce, bananas, maize and beans, is sold locally.

Daniel has requested a third loan of 50,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo.His first and second loans of 25,000 KES were promptly repaid. This third loan is purposely for  purchasing installing irrigation equipment for his banana plantation. He believes the irrigation will mitigate the rampant challenge of insufficient water for farming. He adds that the income generated will be channeled to his children's education and general well-being. 

Daniel reaffirms that the loans from Juhudi Kilimo have improved his family's living standards.

loans.use: to purchase and install irrigation equipment for banana farm.

loans.name: Rosa

texts.en:
Rosa C. is from the village of Miputak. She is 39 years old. Rosa is married and has five children. To make a living, Rosa owns and operates a food stall, from which she sells a variety of foods. Rosa has been engaged in her business for more than two years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Rosa joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Rosa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,900 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Rosa is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw materials for her food vending business. This will be Rosa's sixth loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials for her food vending business

loans.name: Nemesia

texts.en:
Nemesia J. is from the village of Dicayas. She is 57 years old, married and has two school-aged children. Nemesia operates a family member's business; she raises pigs in their backyard. She has been engaged in this business for two months.

In 2011, Nemesia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Nemesia is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase piglets and feed for her business. This will be Nemesia's first loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase piglets and feed

loans.name: Karomat

texts.ru: Фазилова Каромат жительница города Душанбе. Ей 27 лет. Она не замужем. Живет вместе с родителями. У нее средне - специальное образование, швея. Она шьет национальные и свадебные платья. В основном она берет заказы на дому. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже 6 лет. Кредит берет для приобретения новой швейной машинки. Так как её имеющаяся машинка стала плохо шить, и она не успевает с заказами.
texts.en: Karomat F. is a resident of Dushanbe. She is 27 years old, single, and lives with her parents. She has a vocational education as a seamstress. She sews traditional and wedding dresses. Basically, she takes orders and works from home. She has been doing this work for six years.  She is taking out a loan to buy a new sewing machine.  Her old machine has begun to sew badly, and she is behind on her orders.

loans.use: to buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
Editha D. is from the village of Antonino, Labason, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 45 years old. Editha is married and has eight school-aged children. To make a living, Editha sells fish that she has caught. She has been engaged in her business for more than 15 years and earns approximately 15,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Editha joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Editha is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be Editha's first loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additinal fish to sell

loans.name: Men Gel

texts.en:
Men Gel S. is from the village of Santo Niño, Tampilisan, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 35 years old. Men Gel is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Men Gel makes and sells snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Men Gel has been engaged in her business for more than one year and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month for these activities.
