Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. 2. N. Thị Tình (67) là 36 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa. *L. ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva. ."

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future

loans.name: Nhem

texts.en:
Nhem P., 34, resides in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantation. 

P. and her husband sell traditional baskets and palm sugar, earning an income of about US $4 each per day. Each month, the family has to spend US $74 on food and US $56 on the other necessary expenses. 

P. is requesting a loan of US $1,000 to purchase a motorbike to transport the baskets to sell. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike to transport baskets to sell

loans.name: Soy

texts.en:
Soy H., 55, resides in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. 

H. and his wife are farmers, earning an income of about US $3 each per day. Each month, the family has to spend US $74 on food and US $56 on the other necessary expenses. 

H. is requesting a loan of US $700 to purchase mobile spare parts for one of the children to sell. This will be his first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy mobile spare parts to resell

loans.name: Edwin

texts.en:
Edwin is 29 years old and single. He has been practicing mixed farming for the last four years in Litein town in Rift Valley, Kenya. His farm produces milk, which he sells to the local market, and tea, which he sells to Finlay factory. He employs one farmhand. He also earns income from his motorcycle transport business.

Edwin has requested a loan of 50,000 KES through Kiva partner Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says that this loan will enable him to acquire a quality dairy cow that will produce enough milk for sale. He will also be able to use this dairy cow as collateral to acquire more loans in the future. He says that his major challenges are a poor road network and lack of enough knowledge on animal diseases and feeds. He plans to build a modern dairy unit in the future and also acquire more high-yielding dairy cows.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Kalsoom's Group

texts.en:
Kalsoom lives in Khanewal, a small city located in the Punjab province of Pakistan and known for its agriculture industry. She has been living there in a two-room brick house with her family for the past 20 years.
 
She is married to M. A., who has a construction supply business. He deals with different construction companies and also individuals who come to buy construction supplies from him.
  
Kalsoom is a very supportive lady. She operates a milk-selling business at her home. She has a buffalo, a cow and a few goats. She sells their milk to her community clients and earn profits for her family. She is also a very good housewife and fulfills her household responsibilities very well.  

She has three sons and a daughter. Two of them study while her eldest son works in a Punjabi food restaurant for a low income.
  
She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to improve her milk-selling business. With the loan, she will buy another buffalo to increase the production of milk, sell to more clients and increase her profits.
 
She has been operating this business for the past 15 years and is hopeful that an investment will help her further improve it.
 
She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her second loan application. In the previous loan year, she never missed a single meeting and paid her installments on time.

loans.use: to buy another buffalo for the dairy business

loans.name: Shahnaz's Group

texts.en:
Shahnaz  belongs to Khanewal, a small city located in Punjab, Pakistan, and famous for its agriculture industry.

She is a very supportive lady. In addition to her household responsibilities, she sells bangles to financially contribute to the family. She supplies bangles to different gift shops and ladies' cosmetics shops in the market for good profits. 

She also has a buffalo and two cows at home from which she gets milk that she sells to her community clients for profits.
 
Her husband's name is G. H. and he is a fruit vendor by profession. He has a little shop in the market where he offers fresh seasonal fruits to his clients.
 
Shahnaz has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to improve her bangle-selling business. Through the loan, she will buy bangles in larger quantity to fulfill the orders on time and to make better profits. She has been doing this business for the past five years and she is hopeful that an investment will help her improve her business further and increase her profits.
 
She has given birth to a son and a daughter. Both stay at home and don’t attend school because Shahnaz couldn’t afford their education expenses. Now she expects that her income will allow her to enroll them into school in the future.
 
She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her second loan application. She is a responsible client and always paid her installments on time.

loans.use: to buy bangles for selling

loans.name: Kiprono

texts.en:
Kiprono, 37, is married with four children between the ages of 1 and 8. Two of the children are currently attending school. He is a dairy farmer from the town of Litein in Rift Valley, Kenya. He has been in the farming business for ten years and employs one farmhand. He solely depends on the income from his farm to provide for the basic needs of his family.

He has requested a loan of 60,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a motorcycle for transporting his milk to the market. He says that the motorcycle will enable him to reach a wider market for his milk, which will increase his income. His primary challenges in farming have been a poor road network and lack of enough animal feeds. He plans to construct a zero grazing unit in the next five years.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle to transport milk to the market

loans.name: Tasleem's Group

texts.en:
Tasleem lives in a small city of Pakistan called Khanewal. Khanewal is known for its agriculture industry. Her house contains two rooms and she has been living in it for the past 25 years with her family.
 
She is 55 years old, married to A. Y. and has five children. Her first two sons left their education after matriculation and started work. Both of them are rickshaw drivers. Only one of her remaining three is able to continue education and is studying in eighth class.
 
Her husband is a driver, while Tasleem sells milk. For this purpose she has a cow and a buffalo at her home. She takes care of them and sells their milk to her neighboring clients for profits. Along with her business, she also manages her household responsibilities as a mother and wife very well.  

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to improve her business of selling milk. Through the loan, she will purchase another dairy cow to get a larger quantity of milk for selling.
 
She has been operating this business for the past five years and hopes that an investment will not only increase her profits but also add an asset to her business in the form of a cow.
 
She is a new loan applicant and this is her first loan application to Asasah.

loans.use: to buy another dairy cow for the dairy business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Mureedan's Group

texts.en:
Mureedan belongs to Khanewal, a small city of Punjab, Pakistan, known for its agriculture industry. She has been living there with her family in a two-room brick house for the past 20 years.
 
In order to financially support her family she sells milk. She has two cows and a buffalo at her home. She takes care of them and milks them every day. Most of her clients are her community members.
 
Her husband’s name is M. A. and he is a farmer by profession. He grows different seasonal crops and earns good profits after selling them.
  
Mureedan has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s agriculture business. Through the loan, he will purchase fertilizers, seeds and pesticides to grow good quality seasonal crops and to increase his profits.
 
He has been operating this business for the past 10 years and Mureedan is confident that the loan investment will further improve his business.
 
She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her second loan application. In the previous loan year, she established a good credit behavior and attended every meeting.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, seeds and pesticides for the farming business

loans.name: Gibson

texts.en:
Gibson is 25 and married with four children between one month and five years old. Two of his children attend school. For the past three years, Gibson has been a farmer in Litein town in the Rift Valley in Kenya. He employs one farmhand and sells milk to Kabianga Dairies and tea to Finlay Factory in Litein. 

Gibson is requesting a loan of 40,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He will use the proceeds from this loan to build a decent house for his family and pay school fees for his children. Gibson’s major business challenge has been the lack of animal feed. In the future, he plans to build a modern dairy and buy productive dairy cows.

loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Ana

texts.en:
As a married parent of six children, Ana is a very hard working entrepreneur. Ana is 41 years old and has one child who is in school.

Ana has a fish vending business in the Philippines. Ana requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more fish to sell.

Ana has been in this business for 24 years.  In the future, Ana would like to sustain the family needs and repair her fishing boat.

loans.use: to purchase more fish to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a ceramic oven

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
Razia belongs to Pakpattan, a small city of Punjab, Pakistan, known for its dairy industry. Her home consists of two rooms and is located in the area of Khanpura. She has been living there with her family for the past 30 years.
 
She is 40 years old, married to M. M. and has four children. Her husband is well educated, and that’s why all of their children are enrolled in school except the eldest one, who has completed his education and runs a grocery store in the market.
 
Her husband also runs a grocery store in the community through which he sells daily use items like sugar, salt and spices to his clients at cheap rates. He is well known for his good customer dealings among his clients.

Razia is a housewife who stays at home and does her household responsibilities.
  
She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s grocery store business. Through the loan, he will buy groceries in bulk to put into his store to fulfill the demands of his clients and earn better profits.

He has been operating this business for the past 10 years and Razia is confident that an investment will bring better profits and improve his business.
 
She is a new loan user and this is her first loan application to Asasah. 

Note: In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Razia.

loans.use: to buy groceries to sell

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is 47 and married with six children between five and 18 years old. He is a farmer in Kisii Town in South Rift, Kenya, who practices mixed farming. Charles has been a farmer for the past twenty years. He employs two farmhands who work on his farms which produce tea, milk, and bananas for the local market. His retail shop compliments his farming income.

Charles is requesting a loan of 45,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He is currently focusing on rearing dairy cows and hopes to own five good quality dairy cows in the near future. His greatest business challenges are price fluctuation and disease. Charles says that more productive breeds will ensure a good milk supply for his family’s consumption and generate income to educate his children.

loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Lalin

texts.en:
Lalin is 45 years old and married with two children, one of them in school. Lalin works very hard to provide for them.

Lalin runs a general store in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 25,000 loan through NWTF to buy more stock.

Lalin has been in this business for 23 years and sells a variety of items such as dried fish, soap, soft drinks, vegetable, fruits etc. Lalin also earns income from buying and selling charcoal and selling purified drinking water.

In the future, Lalin would like to expand her business and educate her children.

loans.use: to buy more stock to sell

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily D., 46 years old, is a married woman with four children. Her oldest child is 25 years old. 

Emily is engaged in farming. She grows rice, fruits and vegetables. She sells her harvest to her town's market. 

Emily has been in this business for more than 20 years now. She works hard to build her business and earn better.

Emily's loan will be used to purchase farm fertilizers and other supplies. In the future, she hopes for their living conditions to improve.

loans.use: to purchase farm fertilizers and other supplies

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida is 48 years old and married with five children.  Zenaida works very hard to provide for them.

Zenaida runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 28,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more products for the store.

Zenaida has been in this business for four years and sells a variety of items such as sugar, drinks, sardines, bread and purified water. 

In the future, Zenaida would like to add another business like a carinderia (local eatery).

loans.use: to purchase more products to sell

loans.name: Melba

texts.en:
Melba is 51 years old and has six children, one of them in school. Melba is married. Melba is in the agricultural business raising pigs in the Philippines. Melba requested a PHP 25,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional pigs and feed.

Melba has been in this business for 26 years. Melba also earns additional income from fish and food vending.

In the future, Melba would like to send her kids to school and use her income for family needs.

loans.use: to purchase additional pigs and feed

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to construct a zero-grazing unit (barn)

loans.name: Sughran's Group

texts.en:
Sughran belongs to Pakpattan where she owns a small house of two rooms and has been living in it with her family in the area of Khanpura for the past 10 years. Pakpattan is a small city of Pakistan and known for its dairy industry. She is an old married lady, and her husband’s name is H. M. A.. Due to her older age, she spends her time at home and manages the household responsibilities.  She is the mother of a son and four daughters. Her son is the eldest among her children and operates a herbal medicine business. He also treats different diseases by preparing herbal medicines. 
 
Sughran has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the expansion of her son’s business. With the loan, he will buy different herbs to make better quality herbal medicines to treat his patients in a far better way.  He has been operating this business for many years and Sughran is confident that her son’s business will improve further after the loan investment, and her family will be able to live a better life as a result. 

She is a new loan user and this is her first loan application to Asasah. She hopes that it will bring good improvements to her son’s business. 

Note: In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Sughran.

loans.use: To buy herbs for herbal medicine business.

loans.name: Ceferina

texts.en:
Ceferina works hard to support five children. Ceferina is married and has a lumber business in the Philippines.

Ceferina requested a PHP 29,000 loan through NWTF to buy wood.

Ceferina has been in this business for eight years and also earns income from rice dealing.

In the future, Ceferina would like to renovate their house.

loans.use: to purchase lumber

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily is 40 years old and lives in the town of Banga with her family. She is married and has 4 children. Her oldest child is 17 years old, while the youngest is only 4.

Emily is into farming. She grows rice to sell to her community. She also owns and manages a sari-sari store where she sells shampoo, soap and other products.

Emily requested a loan so she could purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs she needs. In the future, Emily hopes for her children to finish college and have bright futures.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Ma. Gina

texts.en:
Ma. Gina is a 37-year-old widow who supports her family by operating three income generating activities: she sells ready-to-wear (clothing, pants and shoes), gets percentage income from Purchase Order Card of a local Department Store and from E-loading.  She lives in Toledo, Cebu. 

Ma. Gina joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past five loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Ma. Gina has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 18,000 helped her earn a monthly income of PHP 15,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her sixth loan, she is borrowing PHP 18,000 to buy more RTW Clothes  so that she can continue to save up for future house renovation. Ma. Gina is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Jannete

texts.en:
Jannete C. is from the village of San Ramon. She is 32 years old and married. To make a living, Jannete owns and operates a direct selling business. The main source of income for the business comes from selling cosmetics products in the local community. Jannete has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Jannete joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jannete is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offerings. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Jannete from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offerings

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie is 54 years old and married with seven children.

She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Rosemarie is borrowing PHP 29,500 through NWTF to purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs and more stock for her general store.

Rosemarie has been raising pigs for 19 years now and has borrowed 19 times in the past from NWTF to sustain her business. She also earns with her general store.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of a dream: expansion of her business.

loans.use: to purchase feed and vitamins for pigs and stock for her general store

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita is 40 years old and married. She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 49,500 loan through NWTF to buy more stock to sell in her General store.

Nenita has borrowed and paid nine loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for three years and also earns an income from viand (food) vending.

Nenita aspires to save enough from her business activities to repair her house and to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
Fe is married with three children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Fe is 54 years old and has one child who is in school.

Fe has a cosmetics sales business in the Philippines. Fe requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy more stock of cosmetics products to sell.

Fe has been in this business for two years.  In the future, Fe would like to put up a new business and expand her cosmetics sales.

loans.use: to purchase more cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Joel

texts.en:
Joel K. is 28 years old, married and blessed with two children. He is a wheat farmer in the Narok area and he has been in this business for the last seven years. 

Joel learned about KADET from one of our credit officers and this will be his first loan. He plans to use the money to buy farm inputs (fertilizers, etc.). He anticipates some profits which he will use to add a number of acres for planting and to start a livestock business.

His dream is to buy and build rental houses on many plots and to provide a better standard of living for his children. He is a conscientious man who aspires to achieve more if funded.

loans.use: to buy farm inputs (fertilizers, etc.)

loans.name: Emerciana

texts.en:
Emerciana works hard to support eight children. Emerciana is married and has a food production/sales business in the Philippines.

Emerciana requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food product (barbeque).

Emerciana has been in this business for eight years and earns more income from refilling purified water.

In the future, Emerciana would like to repair her house.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients for the barbeque she sells

loans.name: Cristita

texts.en:
Cristita is 55 years old and married with two children. Cristita works very hard to provide for them.

Cristita runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to purchase sari-sari store items to sell.

Cristita has been in this business for 10 years and sells a variety of items such as soap, shampoo, curls, oil etc.

In the future, Cristita would like to save her profit for future use.

loans.use: to purchase sari-sari store items to sell

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
As a married parent of five children, Eva is a very hard working entrepreneur. Eva is 47 years old and all her children are in school.

Eva has a buying and selling of used clothing business in the Philippines. Eva requested a PHP 30,000 loan through NWTF to purchase bundles of used clothes.

Eva has been in this business for 16 years. In the future, Eva would like to send their children to school, spend money for house repairs and buy appliances.

loans.use: to purchase used clothes to sell

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
Luzviminda works hard to support five children. Luzviminda is married and has an entertainment (videoke) business in the Philippines.

Luzviminda requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to purchase an additional videoke unit.

Luzviminda has been in this business for 10 years. 

In the future, Luzviminda would like to send her children to school and save.

loans.use: to purchase an additional videoke unit

loans.name: Erna

texts.en:
Erna is a farmer from the town of Banga, South Cotabato. She is 27 years old and married. She has 2 children ages 4 and 2. Erna has been in the farming business for more than 6 years. She grows rice and corn crops to sell to her community. Erna works hard to earn to be able to save for her children's education. She said she only wants the best for them.

Erna's loan will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm inputs

loans.name: Dulcesima

texts.en:
Dulcesima F. is from the village of Rang-ay, Dagatkidavao, Valencia City, Bukidnon. She is 42 years old. Dulcesima is married and has 9 school-aged children. To make a living, Dulcesima owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and raising pigs for sale. Dulcesima has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Dulcesima joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Dulcesima is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Dulcesima from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Gaudilia

texts.en:
Gaudilia R. is from the village of San Ramon. She is 43 years old. Gaudilia is married and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Gaudilia owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Gaudilia has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Gaudilia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gaudilia is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Gaudilia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: I Nyoman

texts.en:
I Nyoman S., age 61, is married and has two children. He works as a chicken farmer. He applied for a loan of 10,000,000 Indonesian rupiah (IDR) which will be used to purchase more chicks. I Nyoman S. plans to save the profits from raising chickens for the future of his children.

I Nyoman S. lives with his wife and one child. One of his children is still attending school. I Nyoman S. spends 50,000 IDR for the costs of his kitchen every day and 200,000 IDR for electricity.

loans.use: to purchase more chicks.

loans.name: Flordeliza

texts.en: Flordeliza is a 40-year-old single woman who supports her family by operating a general store and a snack vending business.   She lives in Balamban, Cebu. Flordeliza joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 12 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Flordeliza has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 20,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 13th loan, she is borrowing PHP 25,000 to buy more curls, candy, soft drinks, shampoo, sardines, and other miscellaneous items so that she can continue to save up for a future business (like RTW) and to renovate their house. Flordeliza is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: to purchase more goods for the store

loans.name: Maria Riselda

texts.en:
Maria Riselda works hard to support her family. Maria Riselda is married and has a ready to wear (clothing) business in the Philippines.

Maria Riselda requested a PHP 11,000 loan through NWTF to buy more products.

Maria Riselda has been in this business for three years now and also earns additional income from her sari-sari store.

In the future, Maria Riselda would like to send her kids to school and have her house repaired.

loans.use: to buy more clothing to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Ederlyn

texts.en:
Ederlyn M. is from the village of Rang-ay, Dagatkidavao, Valencia City, Bukidnon. She is 42 years old. Ederlyn is married and has 4 adult-aged children. To make a living, Ederlyn owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and raising pigs for sale. Ederlyn has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Ederlyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ederlyn is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Ederlyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en: Evelyn is a married woman who lives in Sagay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a general store and a food vending business. Her husband Agustillo, who is 46 years old, works as a helper to earn his living.  They have seven children who are between 13 and 24 years old. Evelyn joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Evelyn has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 9,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 4,500, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her fifth loan, she is borrowing PHP 11,000 to purchase more stock to sell so that she can continue to save up for her children's education. Evelyn is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Ma. Cecilia

texts.en:
As a married parent of three children who are in school, Ma. Cecilia is a very hard working entrepreneur. Ma. Cecilia is 41 years old. 

Ma. Cecilia has a fruit vending business in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to buy fruits and bottled drinks/water to sell.

Ma. Cecilia has been in this business for 12 years.  In the future, Ma. Cecilia would like to continue to send their children to school, spend money for house repairs and buy appliances.

loans.use: to buy fruits and bottled drinks/water to sell

loans.name: Samahani

texts.en:
Samahani S. A. is a 39-year-old lady and a single mother of four children. She runs a poultry business in Likoni and has been in this business for the last year getting good returns.
  
This is Samahani’s first loan from KADET Ltd. and she plans to buy two hundred chickens and two sacks of feed. She anticipates profits which she will use to renovate her rental houses. 

Samahani’s dream is to become a successful business lady and to be able to comfortably provide for her family.

loans.use: to buy two hundred birds and two sacks of feed

loans.name: Torn

texts.en: Torn S., 56, resides in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. S. sell groceries, earning an income of about 4 USD each per day. Her husband is a village chief. He raises ducks to sell, earning an income of 1.66 USD per day. Each month, the family has to spend 60 USD on food and 15 USD on other necessary expenses. S. is requesting a loan of 1,200 USD to purchase more groceries to stock the store. This will be her first from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy more groceries to stock the store

loans.name: Mary Grace

texts.en:
Mary Grace works hard to support two children. Mary Grace is married and has a food vending business in the Philippines.

Mary Grace requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell.

Mary Grace has been in this business for three years. 

In the future, Mary Grace would like to send her kids to school, spend money for house repairs and buy appliances.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth V. is from the village of Rang-ay, Dagatkidavao, Valencia City, Bukidnon. She is 54 years old. Elizabeth is widowed and has 8 adult-aged children. To make a living, Elizabeth owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling vegetables, like stringbeans, amplaya, tomatoes, onion springs and gabe in the local community. Elizabeth has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Elizabeth joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elizabeth is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional green leafy vegetables, like malunggay. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Elizabeth from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional green leafy vegetables, like malunggay

loans.name: Bernagen

texts.en:
Bernagen works hard to support her family. Bernagen is single and has a guitar business in the Philippines.

Bernagen requested a PHP 29,500 loan through NWTF to buy more materials.

Bernagen has been in this business for 20 years now.

In the future, Bernagen would like to expand her business and make house repairs.

loans.name: Samwel

texts.en:
Samwel is twenty-eight years old, and a resident and farmer in Kisii Town in South Rift, Kenya.  He is married with four children, three of whom are in school. He has been an active mixed farmer for the last five years and sells his produce of tea, maize and beans.  His farming business adds to his lumbering income.

Samwel has made a request of 30,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says he will use the income from milk production to first buy three more power-saw machines to boost his lumbering business, then focus on acquiring two more quality dairy cows. He adds that the two businesses will generate enough income to educate his children. 

Samwel notes, like many dairy farmers, that animal feeds and diseases are their greatest worry in the farming business. He remains pleased with Juhudi Kilimo's support but wishes for training.

loans.name: Ranohon's Group

texts.en:
Ranohon M., 48, is the leader of this group. She is a resident of Aravan.  Unfortunately she is a widow. She has five children; two older sons work in construction, a third son who studies at school, and two daughters who help their mom with housework. In 1996 when the collective farms broke up, Ranohon got a piece of land and started to cultivate agricultural products.  She is also engaged in cattle breeding. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase mineral fertilizers. In the future Ranohon wants to see her children get wed.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). 

MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

They live in a one bedroom studio apartment which they bought under a leasing contract. Khongorzul's older two daughters attend a local secondary school and the youngest one attends kindergarten.

Khongorzul has operated a spare parts retail business since 2004. She buys brand new new spare parts from China and sells them in the local market. She also sells secondhand parts, which she buys, fixes and restores. Her business is doing very well because brand new car parts cars are very expensive. Khongorzul has her own customers and her products are in good demand. She has already taken out 3 loans from Credit Mongol and has used them appropriately. Knogorzul is requesting a loan to pay the customs duty on spare parts imported from China.

loans.use: to pay the customs duty on spare parts imported from China.

loans.name: Rolly

texts.en:
Rolly T. is from the village of Mainit, Iligan City. He is 31 years old, married and has 5 school-aged children. Rolly owns and operates a business providing motorela or habal-habal (a motorcycle that is encased in a carriage with 2 rows of seats facing each other) services to local community members. Rolly has been engaged in his business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,500 PHP a month from it.

In 2010, Rolly joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rolly has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI, which was used to to purchase tools needed to maintain his service. Rolly is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase tools and utilities needed to provide service. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Rolly from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase tools and utilities to provide service

loans.name: Altantuya

texts.en:
Altantuya, 25, is married and lives with her husband and a daughter in Arhangai province of Mongolia. They live in a ger, a Mongolian nomadic housing tent, on a small plot of land that they own. They have a decent standard of living. 

Altantuya and her husband operate a computer service center. They used to run this business in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia, between 2006 and 2008. Then they came to live in Arhangai and continued operating their previous business. 

In addition to the computer service business, Altantuya sells women's lingerie at a rented stall. She is a hardworking and sociable person who says, "We want to have our own place where we can operate our business so that we can save money on rent." She is requesting a loan of 3,000,000 Mongolian tugrug (MNT) to purchase computers and other equipment for their computer service center.

loans.use: to purchase computers and other equipment

loans.name: Cheryl

texts.en:
Cheryl T. is from the village of Pagahan, Initao, Misamis Oriental. She is 32 years old. Cheryl is widowed and has two infant children. Cheryl owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, junk food, & beverages in the local community. She also buys and sells coconuts. Cheryl has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. 

In 2010, Cheryl joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Cheryl has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Cheryl is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, junk foods & detergents. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Cheryl from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods, junk food, & detergents

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma works hard to support six children. Norma is married and has a buying and selling of dried fish business in the Philippines.

Norma requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to purchase dried fish.

Norma has been in this business for three years.

In the future, Norma would like to send her kids to school and to finish the construction of their house.

loans.name: Barnohon's Group

texts.en:
Barnohon A. is the leader of this group. She is 42 and married to a private driver. Together they are bringing up a daughter and a son.  Their son, 18, works as a salesman in a store and their daughter studies at school.

Seven years ago Barnohon and her husband, with the initial investment of 5000 soms, started to cultivate agricultural products. At the moment the family prepares their land for cultivating cotton; Barnohon applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase 500 kg of mineral fertilizer and cotton seeds. In the future she dreams of giving her children a good education and of building a sauna near the house.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year.

To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase seeds of cotton and fertilizers

loans.name: Oscar

texts.en:
Oscar M. is from the village of Bolinao. He is 61 years old. Oscar is married and has three adult children. Oscar owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Oscar has been engaged in his business for over 13 years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. 

In 2008, Oscar joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to do business. Oscar has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand his product offerings. Oscar is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the seventh loan taken out by Oscar from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisher-folk and small entrepreneurs.

texts.en:
Badamsambuu, 36, is divorced and lives with his mother in Arhangai province of Mongolia. His mother is retired and stays at home. They live in a ger, a Mongolian nomadic housing tent, on a small plot of land that they own. 

Badamsambuu began selling timber and wood in 2000 in the Hangai wood market of Ulaanbaatar and has been operating it continuously since that time. He is a hardworking and honest person. He is trying to save some more money and buy a truck to operate a goods delivery service in the future. He is requesting a loan of 250,000 Mongolian tugrug (MNT) to buy more timber and for maintenance fees for his car.

texts.en:
Gulbarchyn A. is the leader of this group. She is a resident of Balykchi, a small town in Isykul region. She is 32 and married to a construction worker. Together they are bringing up two sons and two daughters. The youngest daughter is preschool age (under seven) and the other children study at school. 

In order to earn additional money to cover family expenses the family two years ago started to breed livestock. At the moment they have five livestock animals. With money received from the loan Gulbarchyn wants to increase the number of livestock. In the future she wants to improve the family’s living conditions and also repair the house.

Leni has been in this business for six years.  In the future, Leni would like to send her kids to school and expand her business.

Judith requested a loan so she could purchase fertilizer and ducks.

In the future, Judith hopes for her children to be successful.

The main source of income for the business comes from making & selling a variety of ice creams in several flavors in the local community. Elyn has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

loans.name: Azra's Group

texts.en:
Azra lives in Pakpattan, which is a small city known for its dairy industry in the Punjab province of Pakistan. She has been living there in the area of Khanpura with her family in a two-room brick house for the past 30 years.  

A talented lady, Azra operates a business making decoration pieces. She has different business contacts in the market and sells them the decoration pieces at a profit. She is a very active lady and is good at her art.
 
Her husband’s name is A. R.; he is a cobbler by profession and makes shoes on order. He takes orders from different shoe-making factories and shoe shops and fulfills their orders on time to earn an income. 

Azra is the mother of three daughters and two sons. Only her eldest son is able to attend school while the others stay at home.
 
She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the expansion of her husband’s business. He will buy leather, a shoe-polisher and nails in bulk to be able to fulfill larger orders on time. He has been operating this business for past 10 years and has vast experience in his field. Azra hopes that an investment will improve his business further.  

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her second loan application. In the previous loan year, she proved herself a responsible client by paying her installments on time and attending every meeting.

loans.use: To buy leather, a shoe polisher and nails for a shoe-making business

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John has lived more than half of his life in farming to support his family in Kisii Town, in South Rift, Kenya. At age 52 now, he has been in mixed farming for 30 years producing maize, bananas and tea, and selling all the produce locally. He has employed two farmhands in the farm. He is married with six children between the ages of 22 and 16 years old.

John is seeking a loan of 45,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a dairy cow. He says the loan will help him diversify and expand his businesses. He believes the dairy venture will give sufficient nutrients to the family, and ensure consistency in income generated which will be a resource for educating his children.

John is urging financial institutions, and more specifically Juhudi Kilimo, to continue with their support for farmers.

loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Saumu

texts.en:
Saumu T. is married with five children, all of whom attend school. They own a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees. For the past six years, she has operated a business selling farm produce at the market to her neighbours and passersby. In addition, she operates a food vending business which contributes to her income.

Saumu faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of establishing a cereals business in the future. With this 60,000 Kenyan shilling loan, she wants to purchase farm produce for resale. She decided to join Yehu because of its good reputation in society.

loans.use: to purchase farm produce for resale.

loans.name: Erisa

texts.en: Erisa is a hardworking married man with four children, living in his own house in Fort Portal, Uganda. He has been trading in coffee for five years now. The business is promising as he has been able to buy land from coffee savings. He has the hardship of the crop being seasonal, and his dream is to set up a coffee store. Erisa intends to use this loan to buy coffee sell.

loans.use: To buy coffee to sell.

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en:
Samuel O. O. is 35 years old and married. His wife is a business lady and they have three children aged between 13 years and 3 months old. 

His business is located at a fast-growing business center called Kinanie, but he is served by the Kitengela Branch. He owns a computer services business known as Mansam Computer Services. He has been in this business for seven years and has given employment to two people. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenges he has are customers who do not have good knowledge of computers and financial constraints. However. he works very hard from early morning to late evening to keep his business doing well. 

He is using his loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings to buy stationery to grow his business and meet the demands of his customers. He hopes to diversify and start his own construction firm in the future. He describes himself as a visionary man.

loans.use: to buy stationery

loans.name: Kuljamal's Group

texts.en:
Kuljamal J. is the treasurer of this group. She is 50 and married to a driver. Together with her husband, she has raised five children: four daughters and a son. Two daughters are married and live separately with their families, the son works in construction, the third daughter is in the sewing workshop and the youngest daughter graduates a school this year. 

Once Kuljamal applied for a loan and she got 10000 soms, in six months, she repaid the loan and earned an additional 30,000 soms. Since that moment, she has cultivated agricultural products. She also sells dairy products and makes about 200 soms daily. With money received from the loan, she wants to purchase fuel for farming. In the future, Kuljamal wants to purchase a truck for her business.

texts.en:
Simat L. O. K. is 26 years old, married, and he is a father of three children. He is a farmer who has been farming for cash for the past six years with a monthly income of Kshs 5,000. 

This will be his first loan with KADET LTD after he joined and he plans to use the funds to buy farm inputs like seeds, fertilizers and pesticides in readiness for the next planting season. With the profits generated he plans to pay school fees for his children.

He dreams of becoming a prominent farmer. He is a diligent man who works with effort to attain more despite limited resources.
